title: Worlding Sei Shônagon: The pillow book in translation
Pillow book in translation
Project Muse UPCC books
dc.creator: Henitiuk, Valerie
format: ix, 312 p. : col. ill., music ; 21 cm.
description: Contained herein are forty-eight translations1 of what is arguably the single most famous passage in Japanese literature, namely the opening section of The Pillow Book, written around the turn of the eleventh century by a woman we know as Sei Shônagon. The languages represented, in entries dating from 1875 to the present day, are Bulgarian, Catalan, Croatian, Czech, Danish, Dutch, English, French, German, Italian, Romanian, Russian, Spanish and Turkish; two versions have also been provided in Chinese (with additional versions in modern Japanese appearing in Appendix III). Most of the translations have previously been available only in rare or hard to obtain sources, and are now brought together for the first time in an affordable and readily accessible format.

Preface -- Acknowledgements -- Introduction -- Sei Shônagon Classical Japanese -- First generation of western translators -- Second generation -- Third generation -- Fourth generation -- Appendix I. Romanization of original and romanization with English gloss -- Appendix II. A selection of book covers from the translations -- Appendix III. A selection of modern Japanese versions -- Bibliographies.

dc.title: Realizing Autonomy: Practice and Reflection in Language Education Contexts
dc.creator: Irie, Kay. (author.)
description: Realizing Autonomy: Practice and Reflection in Language Education Contexts presents critical practitioner research into innovative approaches to language learner autonomy. Writing about experiences in a range of widely differing contexts, the authors offer fresh insights and perspectives on the challenges and contradictions of learner autonomy.

Cover; Half-title; Title; Copyright; Contents; List of Tables; List of Figures; Acknowledgments; Foreword; Notes on Contributors; 1 Realizing Autonomy: Contradictions in Practice and Context; Part I Goals and Frameworks; 2 Learner Autonomy for International Students: Evolution of a University JSL Program; 3 Experimenting with Autonomy: Learners Teaching Learners; 4 Introducing a Negotiated Curriculum; 5 Creating Space for Learning: Language Learning Materials and Autonomy; Part II Strategies and Scaffolding; 6 Learner Development Through Listening Strategy Training

7 Transformative Learning in Action: Insights from the Practice of Journal Writing8 Scaffolding Economics Language and Learning with Case Studies; 9 The Truth of the Tale: Reconceptualizing Authority in Content-Based Teaching; Part III Collaborative Learning; 10 Creating a Writing Center: Autonomy, Interdependence, and Identity; 11 Who, What, How? Autonomy and English through Drama; 12 Positive Interdependence for Teacher and Learner Autonomy: The Case of the CARTA Program; 13 Parallel Blogging: Explorations in Teacher and Learner Autonomy; Part IV Problems and Possibilities

14 "Nothing to Worry About": Anxiety-reduction Strategies in Harry Potter's Class and Mine15 Responding to Video Journals: Rethinking the Role of Feedback for Learner Autonomy; 16 Listen to Students' Stories: Promoting Learner Autonomy through Out-of-Class Listening Activities; 17 Practical Frustration Busters for Learner and Teacher Autonomy; Afterword: Dogme for Beginners - The Autonomy of the Group; Index
Description based upon print version of record.
